item.title: Offaly man crushed by bull died of head injuries, inquest hears - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Offaly man crushed by bull died of head injuries, inquest hears  Irish Examiner

A man crushed by a bull at a county Offaly farm died due to head injuries, an inquest has heard. Kieran Byrne from Cadamstown, Kinnity, Co Offaly was rushed to Beaumont Hospital where he died on July 19 2018. An inquest into his death opened at Dublin Coroner’s Court heard that the man underwent an operation to save his life at Beaumont Hospital but this was unsuccessful. A file image of a bull The man’s son Jason Byrne gave evidence of the formal identification of his father ahead of a post-mortem examination. Garda David Duffy of Santry Garda Station said he was told by a nurse that Mr By...

item.title: Killer of Justine Valdez died due to gunshot wound to the arm, chest - inquest - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Killer of Justine Valdez died due to gunshot wound to the arm, chest - inquest  Irish Examiner

The killer of student Justine Valdez (24) died from a gunshot wound to his arm and chest. Mark Hennessy (40) was shot by a Garda at Cherrywood Business Park, Co Dublin on May 20 last. Jastine Valdez and her killer Mark Hennessy Family members including Mr Hennessy's parents attended the opening of an inquest into his death at Dublin Coroner’s Court. Mr Hennessy’s father Michael Hennessy stood in the witness box as evidence of how he identified the body of his son was read out in court. “On May 21 2018 at 4.25pm in Dublin City Morgue I formally identified the body of my son to Sergeant Georg...

item.title: Case being considered over death of Jastine murderer - Independent.ie
item.description:
Case being considered over death of Jastine murderer  Independent.ie

Criminal proceedings are being considered after Mark Hennessy, who had abducted and killed a young female student, was shot dead by an armed garda. Hennessy (40) was shot by a garda at Cherrywood Business Park, Co Dublin, on May 20 last. He had previously abducted Jastine Valdez (24) as she walked to her home in Co Wicklow, murdered her and dumped her body. Family members including Mr Hennessy's parents yesterday attended the opening of an inquest into his death at Dublin Coroner's Court. The matter was referred to the Garda Síochána Ombudsman Commission (Gsoc). Yesterday, Senior Investigat...

item.title: Inquest hears 'hard to untangle' shock of burglary and subsequent death of 62-year-old - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Inquest hears 'hard to untangle' shock of burglary and subsequent death of 62-year-old  Irish Examiner

The sudden death of a bachelor that occurred during a burglary at his home was “precipitated” by him having come upon the intruders ransacking his house, a jury has found at the inquest into John O’Donoghue’s death. Mr O’Donoghue, 62, collapsed and died in the front yard of his house at, Toomaline, Doon, Co Limerick, as he approached the house believing the intruders were still inside the property, Limerick City Coroners Court heard. Two members of the gang, David Casey (23), of Carragh Park, Bellcamp, Dublin 17, and Michael Casey, (34), of Clonglong Halting Site, Southill, Limerick, who bo...

item.title: Grand Canyon helicopter crash 'could have been prevented' - The Guardian
item.description:
Grand Canyon helicopter crash 'could have been prevented'  The Guardian

A helicopter crash in the Grand Canyon that killed five British tourists in February could have been prevented, an inquest has heard. James Healy-Pratt, representing the parents of a group of friends who died after the Airbus helicopter plummeted to the ground and caught fire, made the claim at West Sussex coroner’s court during a pre-inquest review on Tuesday. Rebecca Dobson, 26, her boyfriend, Stuart Hill, 29, and his brother, Jason Hill, 31, died in the crash shortly before sunset on 10 February. Their friends Jonathan Udall, 31, of Southampton, and 29-year-old Eleanor Milward, who were ...

item.title: Gardai probed death of premature baby after abortion pills given to paramedics - Independent.ie
item.description:
Gardai probed death of premature baby after abortion pills given to paramedics  Independent.ie

GARDAI investigated the death of a premature baby after a pack of abortion pills was handed to paramedics, an inquest has heard. Baby Angel was born prematurely at 24 weeks on March 4 2017 and died two days later. The cause of death was complications due to extreme prematurity but the cause of prematurity was not known. Dublin Coroner’s Court heard conflicting evidence from the parents of baby Angel, who were sharing a flat in Dundalk, Co Louth. The infant’s mother was not present but her deposition was read out in court. She said around 6am on March 4 an argument with the baby’s father sta...

item.title: Inquest to examine whether SA Police could have prevented woman's death - ABC News
item.description:
Inquest to examine whether SA Police could have prevented woman's death  ABC News

By Claire Campbell An inquest into the death of a woman in Oodnadatta will examine whether South Australian police could have arrested her partner — who was wanted in another state — before he killed her. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that the following story contains the names of people who have died. Serina May Amos, 34, died from blunt force trauma and contributing ischaemic heart disease in the Outback town on July 3, 2015. The coronial inquest heard she was driven to the Oodnadatta health clinic by her partner Danny Ferguson, her sister and brother-in-law an...

item.title: 'It's as if it never happened': Widow 'left in the dark' after her husband's death - ABC News
item.description:
'It's as if it never happened': Widow 'left in the dark' after her husband's death  ABC News

It's been more than a year since the death of her husband in a workplace accident, but Terry Delaney says she's still being left in the dark by authorities. Key points: - Terry Delaney says she's heard little from her husband's employers since his passing - Carl Delaney's death has prompted renewed calls for industrial manslaughter laws - NT Attorney-General Natasha Fyles says the Government will consider its own legislation Carl Delaney was working for a subcontractor on the INPEX Itchthys LNG Project when he was killed on the night of Wednesday, 29 November 2017. His death led the Electri...

item.title: Could the disappearance of one man unravel an entire town? - ABC News
item.description:
Could the disappearance of one man unravel an entire town?  ABC News

By Anna Henderson and Neda Vanovac in Larrimah It's hard to imagine how anyone could keep a secret in a town as tiny as Larrimah. Here, 10 residents live within spitting distance of each other on a featureless stretch in Australia's remote outback, 500 kilometres down the Stuart Highway from Darwin. But almost a year on from the day locals first raised the alarm, the disappearance of Larrimah man Paddy Moriarty, 70, and his kelpie Kellie remains a disturbing mystery. Despite extensive searches, public appeals and a coronial inquest, police appear no closer to unravelling the truth. Larrimah...

item.title: Carl Sargeant lacked pastoral care after sacking, inquest hears - The Guardian
item.description:
Carl Sargeant lacked pastoral care after sacking, inquest hears  The Guardian

A Welsh government minister has told an inquest she did not believe enough pastoral care was given to Carl Sargeant after he was sacked as a cabinet secretary. Lesley Griffiths, the cabinet secretary for energy, planning and rural affairs, also said she thought there should be a formal support network in place for sacked ministers. Sargeant, 49, was found hanged four days after he was dismissed as cabinet secretary for communities and children by the Welsh first minister, Carwyn Jones, after three women alleged inappropriate sexual behaviour against him. The father-of-two was found by his w...

item.title: BBC radio presenter found dead after walking out mid-way through radio show, inquest hears - The Telegraph
item.description:
BBC radio presenter found dead after walking out mid-way through radio show, inquest hears  The Telegraph

A BBC radio presenter found dead at her home hours after leaving work mid-way through her radio show intended to take her own life, a coroner has ruled. Shropshire Coroner's Court was told that Vicki Archer, who left work during a drivetime show, had a history of depression and had made two previous attempts on her life. The 41-year-old, who had emailed a colleague at BBC Radio Shropshire saying she was feeling upset, was found hanged in her house in Woodcote Way, Shrewsbury, on August 6 this year. Coroner John Ellery was told the divorced mother-of-three, who left work at about 5pm, was fo...

item.title: NT Police face race problem with new officer training for 'unconscious bias' - ABC News
item.description:
NT Police face race problem with new officer training for 'unconscious bias'  ABC News

By Neda Vanovac The Northern Territory Police will tackle its perceived race problem by implementing training focused on raising awareness of "unconscious bias", following a series of bungled investigations into the deaths of several people, most of them Aboriginal. Ms Green, 25, died in a vacant lot Tennant Creek, about 500 kilometres north of Alice Springs, in 2013 after bleeding out from a stab wound to her leg that pierced her femoral artery. She was found with her de facto partner Rodney Shannon lying next to her. NT Police admitted during the inquest that they destroyed crucial forens...

item.title: Bridesmaid died after falling and hitting her head on the way to her brother's wedding, inquest hears - The Telegraph
item.description:
Bridesmaid died after falling and hitting her head on the way to her brother's wedding, inquest hears  The Telegraph

A bridesmaid died after falling and hitting her head on the way to her brother's wedding, an inquest has heard. Sammie Bowman, 22, was helping the bridal party with last minute arrangements when she fell over backwards onto concrete. Miss Bowman was rushed to hospital, where doctors operated in an attempt to save her life. However, she died two days later from the devastating brain injury. The inquest at Hull Coroner's Court heard the wedding party had gathered at a rented cottage near Pocklington, East Riding of Yorkshire, for the wedding of her brother Andrew on May 31. The bridal party h...

item.title: Police told not to enter river to rescue drowning man 'because they weren't trained', inquest hears - The Telegraph
item.description:
Police told not to enter river to rescue drowning man 'because they weren't trained', inquest hears  The Telegraph

A police inspector told officers not to enter a river in an attempt to rescue a drowning man because they had no "significant training", an inquest heard. Gary Cross admitted he instructed officers to not try to save John Byrne, a greenkeeper at Wentworth Golf Club, by going into the River Thames. As officers watched from the river bank, Mr Byrne's van became submerged and he drowned. His body was later pulled from the river following the incident at Shepperton, Surrey, in December 2016. The jury of seven men and four women heard that Mr Byrne, 39, had been heard screaming and shouting whil...

item.title: Gerda Dunkel was 82kg when she had weight loss surgery, but within a fortnight she was dead - ABC News
item.description:
Gerda Dunkel was 82kg when she had weight loss surgery, but within a fortnight she was dead  ABC News

By Frances Bell A Perth woman who died after losing her spleen and suffering a heart attack following weight loss surgery may not have been a suitable candidate for the procedure, an inquest has heard. Mother-of-two Gerda Dunkel, 44, had bariatric surgery at St John of God Hospital in the southern suburb of Murdoch in October 2015. The following week she was treated for severe abdominal pain, had her spleen removed and was diagnosed with blood clots. She then suffered a cardiac arrest and died in hospital a week later. A coronial inquest heard that at the time of the surgery Ms Dunkel weigh...

item.title: Allegations against Carl Sargeant 'could not be ignored', inquest hears - The Guardian
item.description:
Allegations against Carl Sargeant 'could not be ignored', inquest hears  The Guardian

The Welsh first minister has told the inquest into the death of a colleague who was found hanged four days after he was sacked from his cabinet post that allegations of inappropriate sexual behaviour made against him could not be ignored. Carwyn Jones said that he had decided to make one last reshuffle before leaving office to bring into government people he believed could replace him. But allegations about Carl Sargeant’s behaviour towards women surfaced. The first minister said: “During the course of discussions about having a general reshuffle, the allegations came forward regarding Carl...

item.title: Inquest hears accidental inhalation of milk a factor in three-month-old baby's death - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Inquest hears accidental inhalation of milk a factor in three-month-old baby's death  Irish Examiner

Aspiration of milk was a factor in the death of a three-month-old baby who became ‘inconsolable’ following a feed. Baby Cormac Lafferty was born with a congenital heart condition in June 2016. His condition was diagnosed with Tetralogy of Fallot, a combination of four related anomalies that commonly occur together. Doctors conducted open-heart surgery a month after his birth placing a shunt to direct blood from the heart to the lungs. Pediatric Cardiologist Dr Damien Kenny told a resumed inquest into the baby's death it was ‘miraculous’ he survived the operation. File photo. Baby Cormac ret...

item.title: Carl Sargeant inquest hears he was found dead days after sacking - The Guardian
item.description:
Carl Sargeant inquest hears he was found dead days after sacking  The Guardian

The wife of the Welsh politician Carl Sargeant found him dead in the utility room of their home four days after he was sacked as a government minister, an inquest has heard. Sargeant, 49, who had been accused of sexual misconduct, was discovered by his wife, Bernie, at the family’s home in Connah’s Quay, north Wales, last year. The north Wales coroner John Gittins said a suicide note was found, and he told the inquest the cause of death was hanging. Traces of antidepressant were found in samples taken from Sargeant’s body. On the first day of the inquest, which is due to last five days, Git...

item.title: Man choked on toast while eating breakfast, inquest told - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Man choked on toast while eating breakfast, inquest told  Irish Examiner

By Louise Roseingrave A nursing home resident choked on a piece of toast while eating his breakfast, an inquest has heard. Gerald Barry (aged 85) was sitting up in his bed at Marymount Nursing Home in Lucan, Co Dublin when he choked on his toast on May 29, 2017. A doctor and nurse examined him that morning and told him he needed to go to hospital for a chest infection. The elderly man initially refused and said ‘no’ but appeared to agree when told his daughter would go with him. Clinical nurse manager Caroline Cusack said she was leaving the room following the examination when Mr Barry beck...

item.title: Welsh first minister 'furious' when Carl Sargeant went public over sacking - The Guardian
item.description:
Welsh first minister 'furious' when Carl Sargeant went public over sacking  The Guardian

The Welsh first minister was “furious” when a senior politician he had sacked amid allegations of sexual misconduct went public about his dismissal, an inquest heard. Carl Sargeant was found hanged at his family home in north Wales four days after he was sacked as a cabinet secretary by first minister Carwyn Jones. It has been claimed during Sargeant’s inquest that Jones “fuelled the despair” of his colleague and friend by giving television interviews about his case the day before he died. On the second day of the inquest, a written statement was read out from Steve Jones, a former special ...

item.title: Labour politician told family he was 'taking easy way out' after MeToo suspension, inquest into his death hears - The Telegraph
item.description:
Labour politician told family he was 'taking easy way out' after MeToo suspension, inquest into his death hears  The Telegraph

A Welsh politician accused of sexual misconduct left a note for his family apologising for "taking the easy way out" and "letting them down", his inquest has heard. Welsh Assembly member Carl Sargeant, 49, was found hanged by his wife Bernadette at the family home in Connah's Quay, North Wales. His death, on November 7, 2017, came four days after being sacked from his role as cabinet secretary for communities and children. The father-of-two was also suspended from the Labour Party over allegations of "unwanted attention, inappropriate touching or groping", seen at the time as the latest wav...

item.title: 'He was our wee fighter' - parents of baby Cormac who died after milk feed - Independent.ie
item.description:
'He was our wee fighter' - parents of baby Cormac who died after milk feed  Independent.ie

The parents of a baby boy paid tribute to their "wee fighter" who offered them "so much hope" during his short lifetime. Baby Cormac Lafferty was born prematurely with a congenital heart condition and his progress through life-saving surgery was described by doctors as "miraculous". Coroner Dr Myra Cullinane returned a narrative verdict at an inquest into the infant’s death. Speaking after the inquest at Dublin Coroner’s Court, parents Ann-Marie and Paul Lafferty said Cormac, who died aged three months, surprised them constantly during his short life. “He beat every target. He was a real fi...

item.title: Prime suspect in teen killing offers to take lie-detector test at inquest - ABC News
item.description:
Prime suspect in teen killing offers to take lie-detector test at inquest  ABC News

By Ellie Sibson A convicted murderer and prime suspect in the cold-case murder of Toowoomba teenager Annette Mason has told a coronial inquest into her death that he is willing to take a lie-detector test on the matter. The 15-year-old was found bludgeoned to death in her house in November 1989 after a night out with friends. A previous inquest found there wasn't enough evidence to find anyone responsible for her death. Allan McQueen, described by police officers and counsel assisting the coroner Adrian Braithwaite as a prime suspect in the police investigation, was sentenced to life in pri...

item.title: Immigration detainee killed himself after self-harming, inquest hears - The Guardian
item.description:
Immigration detainee killed himself after self-harming, inquest hears  The Guardian

A Slovenian waiter killed himself while being held in an immigration detention centre, an inquest jury has found. Branko Zdravkovic, 43, had self-harmed while in detention and had problems with alcohol, Bournemouth coroner’s court was told. The jury returned a verdict of suicide. Although detention centre staff recognised his vulnerability and put him on self-harm watch, no report was sent to the Home Office flagging up suicidal intentions, as required under guidance known as rule 35 (2) . The assistant coroner, Stephen Nicholls, gave the Home Office 14 days to provide further evidence rela...

item.title: VIDEO: Campaigners call for a new inquest into Stardust tragedy - Independent.ie
item.description:
VIDEO: Campaigners call for a new inquest into Stardust tragedy  Independent.ie

Campaigners march from Westland Row to the Attorney General's Office seeking a fresh inquest into the Stardust Fire, which happened in 1981.

item.title: Mother (48) 'in agony' died after being sent home with painkillers - Independent.ie
item.description:
Mother (48) 'in agony' died after being sent home with painkillers  Independent.ie

A coroner has returned a verdict of misadventure in the death of a woman who attended hospital twice in the week before her death complaining of back pain but was sent home with painkillers. Anne Marie O'Brien (48), a mother of four, from Windsor, Castlebar, Co Mayo, died at Mayo University Hospital (MUH) in October 2016 after being treated for severe back pain. An inquest heard she attended MUH on two separate occasions in the week before she died complaining of back pain. She was not admitted on either occasion and was sent home with painkillers. She had a history of chronic obstructive p...

item.title: Kiara Moore: Toddler drowned when car rolled into water after mother left for 2 minutes to get cash - The Independent
item.description:
Kiara Moore: Toddler drowned when car rolled into water after mother left for 2 minutes to get cash  The Independent

A toddler died when the car she was in rolled into a river, after her mother left her alone for just two minutes while she retrieved cash from her office. Kiara Moore, two, was pulled from the River Teifi in Cardigan, southwest Wales in March, and died despite the heroic efforts of police officers who leapt into the river to help. A strong current had dragged her and the car downstream meaning it took two hours to find her, an inquest heard. It was just a week before her third birthday. The court was told that the girl was left alone in the silver Mini for slightly more than two minutes whi...

item.title: Man who served 19 years in jail for top cop's murder found not guilty in retrial - ABC News
item.description:
Man who served 19 years in jail for top cop's murder found not guilty in retrial  ABC News

By Elizabeth Byrne and staff David Eastman, who spent nearly 20 years in jail over the killing of one of the country's top cops, has been found not guilty of the murder after a retrial. A jury found Mr Eastman, now 73, not guilty of murdering senior Australian Federal Police officer Colin Winchester nearly three decades ago. The not guilty verdict in the packed ACT Supreme Court marked the end of a six-month trial and just over a week of deliberating. The tension among police, court staff, journalists and spectators who had spent many days listening to the evidence was palpable. Mr Eastman ...

item.title: Failed suicide bomber found hanged in his cell at HMP Manchester, inquest told - The Independent
item.description:
Failed suicide bomber found hanged in his cell at HMP Manchester, inquest told  The Independent

A failed suicide bomber who was jailed for life after trying to blow up a cafe in Exeter, was found hanging in his cell, an inquest heard. Muslim convert Nicky Reilly, 30, accidentally set off a homemade explosive device in the toilets of a Giraffe restaurant as he prepared to launch a terror attack in May 2008 He succeeded only in injuring himself and was told he would serve at least 18 years in prison after admitting attempted murder at London's Old Bailey. Read more - Westminster terror attacker was lawfully killed, inquest concludes - MI5 may have been able to stop Manchester terror att...

item.title: Mother (76) died after jugular vein was torn during routine surgery - Independent.ie
item.description:
Mother (76) died after jugular vein was torn during routine surgery  Independent.ie

The Health Service Executive (HSE) has offered its "sincerest apologies" to the family of a woman who died after her jugular vein was torn during a routine surgical procedure two years ago. Teresa Lyons's daughter Geraldine O'Brien told her inquest that on the day her mother died, her family were forced to leave her alone in a "hugely overcrowded" emergency department at University Hospital Limerick. The family were told by staff to leave their 76-year-old mother alone in the department as there was only room for patients, Ms O'Brien said. A verdict of medical misadventure was returned at t...

item.title: 'Petrified' witness tells inquest person of interest confessed to killing teen Annette Mason - ABC News
item.description:
'Petrified' witness tells inquest person of interest confessed to killing teen Annette Mason  ABC News

By Melinda Howells A key witness has changed her evidence at the inquest into the 1989 death of Queensland teenager Annette Mason, saying she heard a man confess to killing the 15-year-old. Witness Kylie Nothdurft told the Coroner's Court she was at a barbeque with Allan MacQueen the year after 15-year-old Annette Mason was killed, where she heard him say he had killed the teenager. Ms Nothdurft told police at the time about what she had heard, but said she "froze" when an initial inquest was held in 1991, because Mr MacQueen was in the court room, and she was "absolutely petrified" of him....

item.title: NHS call handlers missed red flags before boy's death, inquest told - The Guardian
item.description:
NHS call handlers missed red flags before boy's death, inquest told  The Guardian

A six-year-old boy died from a treatable blocked bowel disorder after his father made repeated calls to NHS call handlers and his doctor’s surgery asking for help, an inquest heard. Sebastian Hibberd suffered vomiting, diarrhoea and was in excruciating pain during the weekend before his death on Monday 12 October 2015. His father, Russell Hibberd, told the inquest in Plymouth that three separate call handlers from the NHS 111 service failed to recognise the seriousness of his son’s condition. He said that despite several calls to his GP surgery he was not able to speak to a doctor, though h...

item.title: 'We hope the truth will finally be revealed' - calls for new inquest into Stardust tragedy - Independent.ie
item.description:
'We hope the truth will finally be revealed' - calls for new inquest into Stardust tragedy  Independent.ie

The names of all 48 young victims of the Stardust tragedy were read out as campaigners called for a new inquest into their deaths. Families of the victims and their supporters delivered 48,000 signatures to the office of the Attorney General calling for the fresh inquiry. Antoinette Keegan, who lost two sisters in the St Valentine's Day blaze at the Artane nightclub, said: "The public has spoken, 48,000 times." Up to 200 supporters gathered with the families outside Government Buildings, among them singer Christy Moore. He has backed their campaign for justice since the beginning. Speaking ...

item.title: Man crushed to death by forklift truck driven by pet dog - CNN
item.description:
Man crushed to death by forklift truck driven by pet dog  CNN

A farmer was crushed to death last year when his Jack Russell dog pushed a lever inside a forklift truck, causing it to drive into him, an inquest has heard. Dairy farmer Derek Mead, 70, was building a rock garden at his home in Hewish, near Weston-super-Mare in the west of England, when the accident happened in June last year, the UK's Press Association news agency reported. An inquest into Mead's death heard that he left the vehicle in neutral and didn't put the handbrake on when he got out to open a gate on his land. Mead's dog remained inside the vehicle and is thought to have jumped on...

item.title: 'I killed her': Police heard watch house confession, cold case inquest told - ABC News
item.description:
'I killed her': Police heard watch house confession, cold case inquest told  ABC News

By Melinda Howells Two police officers say they heard a man confess to killing Toowoomba teenager Annette Mason just days after she died in 1989, a court has heard. A coronial inquest into the death of the 15-year-old heard that person-of-interest, Allan MacQueen, and his brother Craig Gill were among a group of people arrested and locked up in the city's watch house after a brawl outside the Norville Hotel three days after her body was found on November 19, 1989. Ms Mason was discovered bludgeoned to death in her house and a reopened inquest is trying to determine who killed her. Former po...

item.title: Army admits death of soldier during live-fire exercise was preventable - ABC News
item.description:
Army admits death of soldier during live-fire exercise was preventable  ABC News

By Felicity James The death of a Victorian soldier during a live-fire training exercise in the Northern Territory was preventable and followed a "monumental" failure in training, an inquest has heard. The inquest heard on Tuesday that the Geelong man had been in the Defence Force for 10 months and although he had "field firing" experience, the exercise was his first live-fire urban attack scenario. Counsel assisting the coroner Kelvin Currie told the inquest the Army's training systems appeared to have "monumentally failed" Private Challis. "The level of training of Private Challis and othe...

item.title: Families of men killed in Birmingham wall collapse reject inquest verdict - The Guardian
item.description:
Families of men killed in Birmingham wall collapse reject inquest verdict  The Guardian

The families of five men killed when a wall collapsed at a scrap metal plant in Birmingham have condemned an inquest ruling of accidental death, saying the company’s management should face criminal prosecution. Almamo Jammeh, 45, Ousmane Diaby, 39, Bangally Dukureh, 55, Saibo Sillah, 42, and Muhamadou Jagana, 49, were killed in July 2016 when a 15ft (4.6-metre) wall made of interlocking concrete blocks collapsed as they were clearing out a storage bay at the Hawkeswood Metal Recycling site. An inquest at Birmingham coroner’s court heard the men had to be identified by their fingerprints aft...

item.title: Inmate who died after bullying was let down by prison, inquest finds - The Guardian
item.description:
Inmate who died after bullying was let down by prison, inquest finds  The Guardian

There were serious failings in the care given in prison to a vulnerable woman who died after fellow inmates bullied her and goaded her to take her own life, an inquest jury has found. Jessica Whitchurch, 31, who was described by her family as caring and fun, was discovered unconscious at Eastwood Park prison in Gloucestershire with ligatures around her neck. She died in hospital two days later. She was under observation by staff at the time, having apparently placed other ligatures around her neck less than two hours before. At the end of her inquest in Flax Bourton near Bristol, jurors sai...

item.title: Drunk student who fell into the path of a lorry may have tripped on shoelaces, inquest told - The Independent
item.description:
Drunk student who fell into the path of a lorry may have tripped on shoelaces, inquest told  The Independent

A drunk 17-year-old student may have tripped over her shoelaces causing her to fall into the path of a Tesco lorry as she left bonfire celebrations, an inquest heard. Madeline Burgess had been drinking vodka and was two-and-a-half-times over the drink-drive limit when she was run over by the heavy goods vehicle on the A22 on 11 November last year in East Hoathly, East Sussex. She had visited the annual event with friends but left alone on foot when she became upset about jokes, friends told the inquest in Eastbourne on Thursday. Lorry driver Mark Gonall, from Ashford in Kent, said there was...

item.title: Recycling plant deaths inquest: operations manager 'stunned and perplexed' - The Guardian
item.description:
Recycling plant deaths inquest: operations manager 'stunned and perplexed'  The Guardian

The operations manager of a metal recycling plant where five men were crushed to death by a collapsed wall has said he is “stunned and perplexed” by how the accident could have happened. Almamo Jammeh, 45, Ousmane Diaby, 39, Bangally Dukureh, 55, Saibo Sillah, 42, and Muhamadou Jagana, 49, were killed when a 15ft (4.6-metre) wall made of interlocking concrete blocks collapsed as they were clearing out a storage bay at the Hawkeswood Metal Recycling site in Birmingham in July 2016. An inquest at Birmingham coroner’s court previously heard how the men had to be identified by fingerprints afte...

item.title: No charges to be brought over fatal stabbing of teenager Reece Cullen - TheJournal.ie
item.description:
No charges to be brought over fatal stabbing of teenager Reece Cullen  TheJournal.ie

NO CHARGES WILL be brought in relation to the death of a 16-year-old who died after he was stabbed in the chest. Reece Cullen of Bawnlea Crescent, Tallaght, Dublin 24 died on 5 January 2017 following the stabbing incident at Kilclare Crescent, not far from his home. The Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) found insufficient evidence to prosecute in this case, Detective Inspector John Walshe of Tallaght Garda Station told Dublin Coroner’s Court. At a short inquest hearing at Dublin Coroner’s Court, DI Walshe requested a date for a full hearing into Cullen’s death. “An investigation file wa...

item.title: Inquest opens into the deaths of 10 people shot by British soldiers in August 1971 - TheJournal.ie
item.description:
Inquest opens into the deaths of 10 people shot by British soldiers in August 1971  TheJournal.ie

THE INQUEST HAS opened in Belfast into the deaths of 10 people shot dead by British soldiers almost five decades ago. Scores of relatives packed into the public gallery of court 12 at Laganside Court Complex to hear the opening into the case which has become known as the Ballymurphy Massacre. Those who died over three days in west Belfast between 9-11 August 1971, were: Francis Quinn, 19, Father Hugh Mullan, 38, Noel Phillips, 20, Joan Connolly, 50, Daniel Teggart, 44, Joseph Murphy, 41, Edward Doherty, 28, John Laverty, 20, Joseph Corr, 43 and John McKerr, 49. Barrister Sean Doran QC, repr...
